Description: Mould-made scarab in glazed composition; quite rubbed back with little remains of the modelled mouth and clypeus; at side, rather crude and thick legs, with undercut triangle; underside bearing incised motif arranged vertically with representation of raised cobra (uraeus) looking right and protecting bird (falcon or vulture?) and to the right possible hem sign, above nwb-gold sign; pierced lengthwise; glaze lost; pale yellow, fine core; surface very eroded.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The motif displayed on this scarab does not correspond directly to any known design from the “Scarab Factory” (on its various productions, see Gorton 1996, 91-131; Webb forthcoming). It could represent the divine protection over the pharaoh, or more likely be a cryptic inscription involving the name of Amun (on the cryptic writing of the name of Amun: Drioton 1957, see especially no. 86). For a similar theme on a scarab from Naukratis, but with the motif displayed vertically: see Oxford, Ashmolean Museum AN1896-1908-EA.923. Drioton, E. 1957, 'Trigrammes d'Amon', Festschrift Hermann Junker zum 80. Geburtstag (Wiener Zeitschrift für die Kunde des Morgenlandes 54), Wien, 11-33. Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.), forthcoming, Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum 16th – 17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OC.054) (phase 3)
